Article Title: 'I'll show you what badtameezi is': Air India passenger onboard Kolkata-Mumbai flight threatened over not speaking Marathi; watch viral video
Article Text:
Image credits: Instagram @/mahinergy

A video of a mid-air confrontation on an Air India flight has gone viral after a passenger was allegedly threatened for not speaking Marathi. The incident occurred on October 23 aboard flight AI676 from Kolkata to Mumbai.Content creator Mahi Khan , also known as Mahinergy, who posted the video, claimed that a woman co-passenger demanded he speak Marathi because he was travelling to Mumbai. In the now-viral clip, the unidentified woman is heard saying, "Yes, please do that. You are going to Mumbai, you should know Marathi."The situation escalated when Khan calmly refused and called the cabin crew for assistance. He alleges the woman then threatened him, saying in Hindi, "Get down at Mumbai, I'll show you what badtameezi (misbehaviour) is."In his social media post, Khan wrote: "This isn't just about me, it's about the mindset that's growing dangerously normal. You cannot force a language. You cannot bully respect."Several social media users condemned the incident as being against Maharashtrian culture. One comment noted, "We are Maharashtrian and this is not our culture. It's totally wrong to force someone to speak Marathi."This incident echoes similar language-based conflicts in Maharashtra recently, including a July altercation in a Mumbai local train where a passenger was told to learn Marathi or "get out."
Article Summary: A video of a mid-air confrontation on an Air India flight has gone viral. A passenger was allegedly threatened for not speaking Marathi. The incident occurred on October 23 aboard flight AI676 from Kolkata to Mumbai. NFL’s concussion policy under scrutiny after Brian Daboll and Cam Skattebo violation

On October 24, 2025, the New York Giants were hit with heavy fines after head coach Brian Daboll and rookie running back Cam Skattebo violated the NFL concussion-protocol rules during their Week 6 game versus the Philadelphia Eagles. The incident occurred on October 9, 2025, at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey, when rookie quarterback Jaxson Dart was escorted to the blue medical tent for a concussion check. While Dart was receiving care, Daboll and Skattebo entered the tent area, a zone reserved only for medical staff prompting the league and the players’ union to act.During the third quarter of the game, Jaxson Dart was sacked and held his head on the ground. He was taken to the sideline medical tent for a concussion evaluation. The NFL and NFLPA found that Brian Dabollthe tent and Cam Skattebo subsequently entered and spoke with Dart before his evaluation was complete, actions that constituted a perception of interference.Although the review stated neither Daboll nor Skattebo actually disrupted Dart’s exam or care, their presence violated the policy that “only medical personnel deemed essential to the care of the athlete” may be present during such evaluations.As a consequence, Daboll was fined $100,000, Skattebo $15,000, and the Giants organization faced a $200,000 fine. After the incident, Brian Daboll publicly apologised, explaining:Also Read: “Jaxson Dart Is A Better Player”: Brian Daboll Faces Ruthless Decision After Russell Wilson Pushes Back Against Quarterback Challenge This situation highlights the strictness of the NFL’s concussion-protocol rules, which are in place to protect players like Jaxson Dart and uphold independence in medical evaluations.The league’s joint statement from the NFL and NFLPA emphasised that while Dart’s care was properly managed, the actions of Brian Daboll and Cam Skatteboof interference and therefore violated the protocol.In response, the New York Giants have moved to implement additional staff training and tighter access controls to avoid similar mistakes.Meanwhile, the Giants’ upcoming rematch with the Eagles has extra attention now, not just for the game result, but with this off-field issue fresh in mind. The incident serves as a reminder that even well-intentioned actions can cross the line when player safety protocols are involved.

Article Title: What’s the real story behind the NFL’s $315,000 fine against the New York Giants?
Article Text:
Giants, Brian Daboll and Cam Skattebo fined for violating NFL concussion protocol in Jaxson Dart case (Imagn Images)

Giants fined for violating NFL concussion protocol



League enforces accountability amid concussion concerns



The New York Giants have been slapped with hefty fines after breaching the NFL ’s concussion protocol during quarterback Jaxson Dart’s medical evaluation against the Philadelphia Eagles. The league and the NFL Players Association jointly announced the penalties on Friday, totaling $315,000 in fines. The Giants were fined $200,000, head coach Brian Daboll received a $100,000 penalty, and running back Cam Skattebo was fined $15,000 for conduct deemed detrimental to the league.The incident took place on October 9 at MetLife Stadium, midway through the third quarter when rookie quarterback Jaxson Dart was sacked and remained down on the field, holding his helmet. Following standard concussion procedures, Dart was escorted to the team’s blue medical tent for an evaluation by both the team’s medical staff and an independent neurotrauma consultant.However, the league’s review later revealed that Brian Daboll approached the tent and briefly stuck his head inside, while Cam Skattebo entered the tent before the evaluation concluded. Under the NFL’s concussion protocol, only essential medical personnel—such as the club physician, athletic trainer, and independent consultant—are allowed to be present during a player’s examination.A joint NFL–NFLPA statement said the coach and player’s actions “created the perception that they were interfering with Dart’s exam.” Although the investigation found no evidence that either man influenced the evaluation or Dart’s medical care, it concluded that “their conduct was inconsistent with and demonstrated a disregard for the concussion protocol’s requirements and therefore constituted a violation. ”Daboll was seen speaking animatedly with team doctor Scott Rodeo while waiting to learn if Dart would be cleared to return. After the game, Daboll said he only wanted to check on his quarterback’s condition and determine if a timeout was needed before a potential fourth-down play. Still, the league considered his action a breach of established medical boundaries.The NFL emphasized that the Giants’ medical staff properly followed all the necessary steps of the concussion protocol. The organization has since introduced remedial measures, including refresher training for players and staff, and new access rules to ensure only authorized individuals enter the medical tent during an evaluation.The league said these corrective actions were considered when determining the fines.The NFL’s concussion protocol remains a closely watched area of league policy, particularly following high-profile incidents like Tua Tagovailoa’s head injury in 2024. The joint NFL–NFLPA system conducts automatic reviews of all potential breaches to safeguard player health and ensure compliance.Dart later cleared all return-to-play procedures and finished the game, helping the Giants secure a 34–17 victory over Philadelphia.Despite the controversy, Daboll took full responsibility for his mistake, admitting he expected the fine but emphasizing his concern was purely for Dart’s well-being—a costly but crucial reminder of the boundaries set by the league’s player safety protocols.Also Read: “She treated us like gold": What Travis Kelce’s coach experienced while meeting Taylor Swift shows why everyone loves her so much
Article Summary: New York Giants fined $315,000 for violating NFL concussion protocol. Head coach Brian Daboll and running back Cam Skattebo also fined. Incident occurred during quarterback Jaxson Dart's medical evaluation against the Philadelphia Eagles. NFL says only essential medical personnel are allowed to be in medical tent during evaluation.

On Friday night, NBA Commissioner Adam Silver finally addressed the scandal, describing it as “deeply disturbing.”Speaking during Amazon Prime Video’s broadcast of the Celtics–Knicks game, Adam Silver admitted that the news left him reeling. “My initial reaction was I was deeply disturbed,” Silver said. “There’s nothing more important to the league and its fans than the integrity of the competition. I had a pit in my stomach. It was very upsetting.”Federal prosecutors allege that Rozier conspired with associates to manipulate betting outcomes by leaking insider information and deliberately underperforming. In one instance from March 2023, Rozier allegedly told partners he would leave a Charlotte Hornets game early with a supposed injury, helping bettors win more than $200,000 in wagers.Meanwhile, Billups is accused of taking part in rigged poker games backed by organized crime. According to investigators, the games used x-ray tables and pre-marked cards to defraud players of millions of dollars. The FBI said the operation was connected to New York’s Bonanno, Gambino, Lucchese, and Genovese families.Silver confirmed that both men have been placed on administrative leave while the league cooperates with federal authorities. “I apologize to our fans that we are all dealing with this situation,” he said. The commissioner also revealed that the NBA previously looked into Rozier’s betting activity in 2023 but found “insufficient evidence” to take action.“We frankly couldn’t find anything,” Silver explained. “Terry at the time cooperated. He gave the league office his phone. He sat down for an interview. And we ultimately concluded that there was insufficient evidence despite that aberrational behavior to move forward. He still hasn’t been convicted of anything, in fairness to Terry. Obviously, it doesn’t look good. But he’s now been put on administrative leave. There’s a balance here of protecting people’s rights and investigating.”The scandal has reignited debate about the NBA’s deep integration with the gambling industry. With partnerships involving FanDuel and DraftKings, betting is now woven into the league’s broadcasts and marketing. Coaches across the league voiced concern that this close relationship may have blurred ethical lines.“It’s really sad,” said Milwaukee Bucks coach Doc Rivers. “The outside world, in my day, couldn’t get to us. And now they can, with ease.”Detroit Pistons coach J.B. Bickerstaff added, “Once you introduce gambling that the sports world has now, there’s going to be some very dangerous situations out there for everybody.”The league has emphasized its strict monitoring systems and educational programs for players and staff. As of now, the FBI’s investigation is going on.Also Read: Explained: What is the NBA gambling case? Who has been arrested? Is LeBron James involved?
Article Summary: Adam Silver says arrests left him “deeply disturbed” amid NBA gambling scandal. NBA faces renewed pressure over its ties with betting companies. Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups and Miami Heat guard Terry Rozier arrested in federal gambling investigation.

Article Title: Was Michael Porter Jr targeted after Jontay Porter’s NBA gambling scandal went public? Brooklyn Nets forward reveals harrowing details
Article Text:
Michael Porter Jr. Image via: Evan Bernstein/ Getty Images

Michael Porter Jr. opens up on family turmoil after Jontay’s gambling scandal



Michael Porter Jr. Image via: Ron Chenoy-Imagn Images

Michael Porter Jr. seeks stability with the Brooklyn Nets amid scrutiny



NBA gambling scandals have been a huge nightmare for the league, as they sometimes involve stars and other employees. Amid the current gambling scandal that led to the arrest of Chauncey Billups and Terry Rozier, the new Brooklyn Nets forward, Michael Porter Jr. , reveals the horrible aftermath of the gambling scandal involving his brother, Jontay Porter.The NBA gambling scandal that rocked the league this year has left deep scars — and few felt it as personally as Michael Porter Jr. While the Brooklyn Nets forward was not directly linked to the investigation, he became an unwilling participant in the storm surrounding his younger brother, Jontay Porter. Now, Michael is breaking his silence about the ordeal and the chilling threats that followed once the scandal became public.Investigations into illegal betting operations and underground poker rings led to the arrests of Chauncey Billups, Terry Rozier, and Damon Jones. But behind the headlines, court filings from the Eastern District of New York revealed a darker subplot — gamblers had threatened Jontay Porter to ensure his cooperation in their schemes. For Michael, learning the truth came as both a relief and a shock.“Yeah, me and Jontay actually recently sat down and had a conversation and spoke for the first time.He told the extent of his story for the first time to me,” Michael, 27, told The New York Post.“And that was recently, and those details were kind of relayed to me. But for a long time I was kind of on the outside looking in as well, because for a long time he wasn’t trying to involve the family because of the fact that the people that were involved were dangerous people.”Michael Porter Jr. has made his Brooklyn Nets debut, but the performance with his new team has reflected the weight of distraction and pressure. In his debut, he struggled on both ends of the floor, posting just 12 points on 5-of-15 shooting in a 136-117 loss to the Hornets.“I just didn’t feel like I was as fresh as I needed to be,” Porter admitted postgame, adding that the entire team “was probably a little bit more sluggish, a second too slow.”Porter himself knows the road ahead demands more focus. “Yeah, I’ve got to be locked in every possession. Defensive rebounding,” he said, acknowledging the team’s lack of size. “I’ve got to kind of be a rim protector a little bit more, and just be locked in every possession.”In their next matchup on October 24, the Cleveland Cavaliers beat the Brooklyn Nets, 131-224, but Porter secured a standout 31 points in 36 minutes of play.Also Read: NBA Commissioner Adam Silver breaks silence after Chauncey Billups and Terry Rozier arrested in NBA gambling probe

Michael Porter Jr. reveals the horrible aftermath of the gambling scandal involving his brother, Jontay Porter. The Brooklyn Nets forward was not directly linked to the investigation, but became an unwilling participant in the storm surrounding his younger brother.
